verses.text: David counted the people who were with him and set commanders of thousands and commanders of hundreds over them.
verses.comment: Follows standard Hebrew ordering of rank.

verses.text: David sent out a third of the people under Joab, a third under Abishai the son of Zeruiah, Joab’s brother, and a third under Ittai the Gittite. And the king said to the people, 'I myself will also go out with you.'
verses.comment: Names and divisions are as in the original text.

verses.text: But the people said, 'You must not go out. For if we flee, they will not care about us. Even if half of us die, they will not care about us. But you are worth ten thousand of us; so it is better that you help us from the city.'
verses.comment: Clarified for modern English while preserving ancient idiom.

verses.text: The king said to them, 'Whatever seems best to you, I will do.' So the king stood beside the gate while all the people went out by hundreds and by thousands.
verses.comment: Captures the Hebrew phrase 'by the hand of hundreds and by the hand of thousands.'

verses.text: And the king commanded Joab, Abishai, and Ittai, saying, 'Deal gently with the young man Absalom for my sake.' And all the people heard when the king gave all the commanders orders about Absalom.
verses.comment: Preserves the command to treat Absalom gently.

verses.text: So the army went out into the field against Israel, and the battle took place in the forest of Ephraim.
verses.comment: The 'forest of Ephraim' is a location east of the Jordan.

verses.text: There the army of Israel was defeated by David’s servants, and the slaughter there that day was great—twenty thousand men.
verses.comment: The text specifies the high fatality of Absalom's army.

verses.text: The battle spread over the entire countryside, and the forest devoured more people that day than the sword devoured.
verses.comment: 'The forest devoured' is a Hebraic phrase for deaths by natural causes or terrain.

verses.text: Absalom happened to meet the servants of David. Absalom was riding on his mule, and as the mule went under the thick branches of a large oak tree, his head got caught in the oak, and he was left hanging between heaven and earth while the mule that was under him went on.
verses.comment: Renders the Hebrew for 'head caught in the oak.'

verses.text: A certain man saw this and told Joab, 'Look, I saw Absalom hanging in an oak tree.'
verses.comment: The report is relayed in direct speech.

verses.text: Joab said to the man who had told him, 'You saw him? Why then did you not strike him to the ground? I would have given you ten pieces of silver and a belt.'
verses.comment: Translates 'shekels of silver' as 'pieces of silver' for clarity.

verses.text: But the man said to Joab, 'Even if I were to receive a thousand pieces of silver in my hand, I would not reach out my hand against the king’s son. For we heard the king command you, Abishai, and Ittai, saying, “Protect the young man Absalom for my sake.”'
verses.comment: Renders 'protect' literally.

verses.text: 'Otherwise, if I had acted treacherously against his life, and nothing is hidden from the king, you yourself would have stood aloof.'
verses.comment: 'Stood aloof' reflects distancing oneself as the original text suggests.

verses.text: Then Joab said, 'I will not waste time like this with you.' And he took three spears in his hand and thrust them into Absalom’s heart while he was still alive in the midst of the oak tree.
verses.comment: 'Spears' translated from 'shafts' or 'javelins' in Hebrew.

verses.text: And ten young men who carried Joab’s armor surrounded Absalom and struck him and killed him.
verses.comment: Indicates finality of Absalom's death.

verses.text: Then Joab blew the trumpet, and the army returned from pursuing Israel, for Joab restrained the people.
verses.comment: The trumpet signal stops the battle.

verses.text: They took Absalom and threw him into a great pit in the forest and piled up a large heap of stones over him. And all Israel fled, each to his tent.
verses.comment: A heap of stones is symbolic of disgrace and memorial.

verses.text: Now Absalom in his lifetime had taken and set up for himself a pillar that is in the King's Valley. For he said, 'I have no son to keep my name remembered.' He called the pillar after his own name, and to this day it is called Absalom’s Monument.
verses.comment: See 2 Samuel 14:27 regarding Absalom's sons; possibly they had died.

verses.text: Then Ahimaaz the son of Zadok said, 'Let me run and carry news to the king that the LORD has avenged him of his enemies.'
verses.comment: Ahimaaz is the priest’s son and a messenger.

verses.text: But Joab said to him, 'You are not to be a bearer of news today; you may report on another day, but today you must not bear news, because the king’s son is dead.'
verses.comment: Joab spares Ahimaaz from delivering bad news.

verses.text: Joab said to the Cushite, 'Go, tell the king what you have seen.' The Cushite bowed before Joab and ran.
verses.comment: The identity of the 'Cushite' suggests an African origin.

verses.text: Then Ahimaaz the son of Zadok again said to Joab, 'Whatever may happen, let me also run after the Cushite.' Joab said, 'Why do you want to run, my son, since you will have no reward for your news?'
verses.comment: Ahimaaz persists despite Joab’s warning.

verses.text: 'Come what may,' he said, 'I will run.' So Joab said, 'Run.' Then Ahimaaz ran by the way of the plain, and outran the Cushite.
verses.comment: Ahimaaz takes a faster route and arrives first.

verses.text: Now David was sitting between the two gates, and the watchman went up to the roof of the gate by the wall and looked up and saw a man running alone.
verses.comment: The ancient walled city had two gates for security.

verses.text: The watchman called and told the king. The king said, 'If he is alone, there is news in his mouth.' And he drew nearer and nearer.
verses.comment: Running alone indicated he was a messenger.

verses.text: Then the watchman saw another man running, and he called to the gatekeeper and said, 'Look, another man running alone.' The king said, 'He also brings news.'
verses.comment: Multiple runners suggested multiple reports.

verses.text: The watchman said, 'The running of the first seems to be like the running of Ahimaaz the son of Zadok.' The king said, 'He is a good man and comes with good news.'
verses.comment: David trusts Ahimaaz to bring favorable news.

verses.text: Then Ahimaaz cried out to the king, 'All is well!' He bowed down before the king with his face to the ground and said, 'Blessed be the LORD your God, who has delivered up the men who raised their hand against my lord the king.'
verses.comment: 'All is well' translates 'Shalom.'

verses.text: The king said, 'Is it well with the young man Absalom?' Ahimaaz answered, 'When Joab sent the king’s servant, your servant, I saw a great commotion, but I do not know what it was.'
verses.comment: Ahimaaz withholds the truth about Absalom's death.

verses.text: The king said, 'Turn aside and stand here.' So he turned aside and stood still.
verses.comment: The king dismisses Ahimaaz to wait.

verses.text: And behold, the Cushite came, and the Cushite said, 'Good news for my lord the king! The LORD has delivered you today from all those who rose up against you.'
verses.comment: The Cushite is the true bearer of news.

verses.text: The king said to the Cushite, 'Is it well with the young man Absalom?' The Cushite answered, 'May the enemies of my lord the king, and all who rise up against you for evil, be as that young man.'
verses.comment: 'As that young man' is a tactful way to say Absalom is dead.

verses.text: Then the king was deeply moved. He went up to the chamber over the gate and wept. And as he went, he said, 'O my son Absalom, my son, my son Absalom! Would that I had died instead of you, O Absalom, my son, my son!'
verses.comment: David’s lament captures the depth of his grief. Hebrew idiom preserved.
